across top, black ink: ON THE STREETS OF PHiLADELPHiA FROM COLONiAL Times to Late 1940's. One could hear the CRY of the PHiLADELPHiA PEppER-Pot WOMAN, / For She is the Beginning History-Maker of Afrikan Amerikan Cooking.
upper L, black ink: Study
lower right, black ink: Around the 1800's, one / would see the PEPPER-POT / WOMAN pushin' her cart of / PEPPER-POT-Soup, cryn' / HOT PEPPER, / HOT PEPPER / POT SOUP! / 3 [cents] A cup! / Git Hot Soup! / Hot PEPPER Soup!
markings: Fort Gansevoort gallery label at center verso frame
medium: Watercolor, pen and ink, and collaged buttons and fabric on paper
signed: CL, black ink: aminah Brenda L. Robinson 1989
text: Aminah Robinson routinely chose themes and subjects drawn from Black culture and experience. In this watercolor and collage from 1989, Robinson alludes to the tradition of formerly enslaved Africans and their decendants engaged in entrepreneurial trades and pursuits as means of survival. Here, Robinson depicts a architypcial "Pepper Pot Woman, " who from colonial times until the late 1940s, sold hot pepper soup from a pushcart on the streets of Philadelphia. In handwritten text Robinson inserted across the top of the drawing, she notes that early street vendors like the Philadelphia pepper pot woman, represented the historical origins of African American cooking.
title: Philadelphia Pepper Pot Woman
